case_vignette:
A 42-year-old man presents with a four-day history of experiencing headache, malaise, and stabbing right-sided headache. Two days after his initial symptoms appeared, he developed a rash over the area of pain. He reports that he went hiking through the Texas hill country prior to becoming ill. The patient is otherwise in good health and has an unremarkable medical history. Physical examination reveals unilateral erythematous, thin, raised plaques over the right forehead. In addition, he has no relevant social or family history. The patient is a 42-year-old man who is otherwise healthy and has no significant medical history. He reports that he went hiking in the Texas hill country prior to becoming ill. The patient's symptoms began four days ago with headache, malaise, and stabbing right-sided headache. Two days after his initial symptoms appeared, he developed a rash over the area of pain. The patient's physical examination reveals unilateral erythematous, thin, raised plaques over the right forehead. The patient is otherwise in good health and has an unremarkable medical history. The patient is a 42-year-old woman who is otherwise healthy and has no significant medical history. She reports that she went hiking in the Texas hill country prior to becoming ill. The patient's symptoms began four days ago with headache, malaise, and stabbing right-sided headache. Two days after her initial symptoms appeared, she developed a rash over the area of pain. The patient's physical examination reveals unilateral erythematous, thin, raised plaques over the right forehead. The patient is otherwise in good health and has an unremarkable medical history.
Original text:
A 42-year-old man presents with a four-day history of experiencing headache, malaise, and stabbing right-sided headache. Two days after his initial symptoms appeared, he developed a rash over the area of pain. He reports that he went hiking through the Texas hill country prior to becoming ill. The patient is otherwise in good health and has an unremarkable medical history. Physical examination reveals unilateral erythematous, thin, raised plaques over the right forehead. In addition, he has no relevant social or family history. The patient is a 42-year-old man who is otherwise healthy and has no significant medical history. He reports that he went hiking in the Texas hill country prior to becoming ill. The patient's symptoms began four days ago with headache, malaise, and stabbing right-sided headache.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?

I've been experiencing a headache, general feeling of discomfort or uneasiness, and a stabbing pain on the right side of my head for the past four days. Additionally, two days ago, I developed a rash over the area where I feel the pain.
Can you describe the rash? Is it blisters, redness, or anything else?
The rash consists of red, thin, raised plaques on the right side of my forehead.
Have you experienced this type of rash or similar symptoms in the past?
No, I have not experienced this type of rash or similar symptoms in the past.
Do you have any pre-existing medical conditions or are you currently taking any medications?
I am in good health and do not have any significant medical history or take any medications.
Does the rash spread beyond the hairline, or have you noticed it on other parts of your body?
The rash is only over the right side of my forehead and has not spread beyond that area.
Is there any tingling, burning sensation, or increased sensitivity in the area of the rash?
No, I haven't experienced any tingling, burning sensation, or increased sensitivity in the area of the rash.
Have any of your close family members ever experienced similar symptoms?
No, my family history does not reveal anyone having experienced similar symptoms.
Final Diagnosis: Temporal arteritis

The rash is localized only on the right side of the forehead and has not spread beyond that area. There are also no reported sensations of tingling, burning, or increased sensitivity in the affected area. Furthermore, there is no family history suggesting that relatives have had similar symptoms.
